question.body: Which of the following is not an example of the physiological phenomena of adaptation?

multiple_choice.choice: after putting on a shirt in the morning, you aren’t aware of the fabric against your skin most of the rest of the day

after you have been in a room with scented candles burning for a while, you don’t smell the scent as strongly any more. But if the candles started a fire so that other things were burning, you would quickly detect that new smell
when skin is being burned it hurts, but if the burn goes deep it stops hurting
as you eat a spicy meal, the flavor may be intense initially and gets less noticeable as you eat more

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is an example of touch receptors adapting, sending fewer signals as long as the pressure of the fabric remains relatively constant.
Incorrect. This is an example of olfactory receptor adaptation and only a change in odor will initiate more signals.
Correct. Nociceptors typically do not adapt; the reason a deep burn may stop hurting is because the receptors themselves have been damaged and can no longer send any signal.
Incorrect. Taste receptors adapt rapidly, sending fewer signals with continued stimulation by a particular taste.

part.hint: Special sense receptors will also adapt similarly to some of these somatosensory receptors.
